awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Scaling and Prioritizing Market-Sized Application Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergence of smartphones and more generally mobile platforms as a vehicle for communication, entertainment, and commerce has led to a revolution of innovation. Markets now provide a dizzying array of applications that inform and aid every conceivable human need or desire. At the same time, application markets allow previously unknown multitudes of application developers access to user devices through fast- tracked software publishing with well-documented consequent security concerns. The science and tools for performing security analysis of applications have vastly improved over the last decade. However, market providers have limited capability to apply those analyses at scale to the massive software markets. 

This project is a crosscutting research, educational, and outreach plan improving the scalability and accuracy of smartphone application analysis. The research effort focuses on the creation of new techniques and algorithms to enable analysis of large bodies of applications by reducing analysis cost and prioritizing identified security vulnerabilities by their expected impact.  Explored within the context of Android Intent analysis resolution, the team is developing efficient algorithms and study the computational complexity of matching application communication sources and sinks thereby supporting phone-wide information flow analysis, developing empirical models for estimating the likelihoods of inter-component communication, and exploring features and metrics indicating their potential security impacts communication pathways.  The approaches are being applied to a commercial markets (Apple iOS) and domains (web, desktop, and server environments) and massive application data sets.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new techniques for the evaluation

of applications on mobile platforms.  The tangible outputs of this

project are techniques and tools for constructing market

certification services. Research had three thrusts:

 

Representation recovery: The first thrust focussed on the recovery of representations of

applications from installation images.  Principally, this involved the

recovery of Java .class files from the Dalvik bytecode, which enabled further analysis..

Principally, this involved the

recovery of Java .class files from the Dalvik bytecode. We also

re-architected the Android-specific ded decompiler based on the

formalized intermediate representation, TyDe (TYped DEx). As part of

this effort, we will formalize and improve dex type inferencing,

manage ill-formed bytecode structures, and create a generalized

Dalvik-to-Java retargeting logic based on bytecode instruction

templates. These techniques are widely used in industry and the  research community.

 

Analysis framework: The second thrust investigated a  framework for performing deep

analysis of mobile code including: (a) whole-program analysis, (b)

data-flow analysis to detect possible exfiltration, (c) analysis of

reflection, (d) analysis of dynamic loading of application code,

and (e) use of machine learning (ML) to reduce false positives. Outcomes from this thrust really pushed the state of the art for mobile-application analysis.

 

The third thrust focussed on the analysis of the application meta-data and provider. In other words, this thrust took techniques from the previous three thrusts and scaled them to market scale.


We have released  tools (Dare and Epicc) that were developed as part of this project. Please see http://docteau.github.io/tools.html.  Several research groups and industrial groups are using these tools. The major impact of this project has been to enable large scale analysis of mobile applications. Several industrial and research groups are using these tools. As result of techniques and tools developed as part of this project, the mobile application marketplaces are safer.




 

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2023
Modified by: Somesh Jha
